Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Ensure the safe and punctual operation of the subway train.
Situation2: A minor signal delay up ahead requires careful speed adjustments to maintain the schedule without causing abrupt movements.
Story: I glanced at my phone during the brief lull at the station, my stepbrother’s message lighting up the screen: “Don’t forget, dinner’s at seven. Mom really wants you there.” I could almost hear the hope in his words, the unspoken plea for me to show up, to be part of the family, to not let them down again. But as the doors slid shut and the train hummed to life, my focus snapped back to the control panel. Dispatch crackled in my ear—there was a minor signal delay ahead. I’d have to adjust the speed, keep the ride smooth, and make up lost time if I could. The city depended on me to get them home safely and on time. My hands hovered over the controls, my mind split between the tracks stretching out before me and the empty seat that would be waiting at the dinner table. The weight of both worlds pressed in, each demanding my presence, each unwilling to yield. My heart thudded in my chest as I tried to figure out which promise I was about to break.
